Text: The President's sanctions package is a significant, but very measured step. We have many options left in our sanctions arsenal should #Russia continue to move against #Ukraine. The next step is to apply these sanctions to foreign subsidiaries of U.S. corporations. (3/3)

I have long been an advocate of sanctioning Russian sovereign debt; with Russian borrowing at a 15 year high, these sanctions will impose significant economic pressure directly on the Russian govt and protect American investors from indirectly financing Putin's agenda. (2/3)

I applaud @POTUS for including enhanced Russian sovereign debt as part of a significant sanctions package announced yesterday to combat Russian aggression against Ukraine. (1/3) https://t.co/zHa2vcC1oY
If the Europeans don‚Äôt want restrictions on buying Russian oil and gas and want Russia to stay in the SWIFT international banking system, sanctions won't do much to deter Putin.

We should remember: Sanctions against Russia will impose costs on Americans too.
If Russia in effect forces #Ukraine to enter into a treaty forswearing ever joining NATO, we should impose some sanctions. (3/3)
However, the Russian invasion could be a disaster for #Ukraine and Europe. Ultimately this is a decision to be reached by Ukraine, and America should not pressure Zelensky. (2/3)

#Ukraine may need to choose between entering into a treaty with Russia forswearing ever joining NATO, or face invasion. Such a treaty commitment impairs Ukraine‚Äôs options in the decades to come and sets a bad international precedent. (1/3)
